To my L Treasuro
r
N
o
12. 89

page.lettertext:
Belgia 1589 21 Novem
b
To my Lord Tresurer from M
r
Bodly
It may please yo
r
L. since
e writing of my last, wee have had
e
ennemy about
e sconse of
Rees,
w
ch
e souldiers in yt, either of
cowardise w
ch
is
e co
m
on opinion, or for
t
as they alleadge yt was
not possible to hold yt surrendred p
nt
ly, the losse ys estemed to bee
great & such as will turne the Province of
Guelders
into very much
trouble espetially yf those of
Sgravenwert
c
o
tinew theyr muteny
w
ch
is not oth
r
waies likely, For theyr demaund doth amount to above e somme of 10000
[ls]
st
rs
w
ch
is not heer to be had, they are
also fall
e
into conference w
th
e
Counsell
of
e
Duke of Cleave
who
as we are informed ar exceding desirous to compas
e place. Yt is
now in consultation heer, wheth
r
yt be expedient or not to send
againe
e English forces into those quarters for yt is not thought
that
e Ennemy doth ly so strong; but
t
he may easily be repulsed
Howbeit ther ys nothing yet resolved. There ys also an oth
r
new
muteny growen in
e castell of
wijke
a place of greate
importance, about 2 leagues from
Utrecht,
up
o
e River, where
e garrison refuseth to yeeld obedience to
e
States,
desireth to bee
discharged of theyr othe & requreth to Rx their full count & reckening.
The State ys much troubled about yt & can not resolve, wether yt
be best to give them present contentment w
th
out attending how to
winne them in time, or in regard of
e Example & consequence to
proceed w
th
violence against th
e
, generally theyr gov
r
ment heer
hath so littel credyt & countenance & is so altogeth
r
voyd of good
order, & of all
t
should plant eith
r
feare or love in
e peoples
affections,
t
wee finde in most men a werines to be subject to
sons of no more vertue, & worthe. But befor
e Countrey be reduced
to some dange
r
ous extremity, this gen
r
all discont
e
tment will hardly
break out w
ch
maketh me think
t
yf hir
Ma
ties
first resolution
about
e sending heth
r
of my
L. of Buckhurst
had tak
e
place
There might have bin much offred to hir Hig
nes
good liking, but I
dout at
is p
nt
the good succes of his coming./ For these fewe
that beare
e swaie amonge
e gen
r
all States will nev
r
yeeld in
any likelihode unles they bee forced for feare of
e people to any
alteration
t
may lessen theyr autority, so that for mine owne
te I
do think they wilbut use my L. yf they can as an instrument to
retourne such disorders as they will present against hir Ma
ties
assistance
& in regard of
em selves condiscend to nothing, that may
s
ve to
establish a bett
r
regiment in
e affaires of
e Country, wh
r
in I trust
to yo
r
L. accustomed favour for interpreting to
e better
te this
bold delivery of my simple opinion.
Count Hollock
who is commonly
heer at
e Hage doth retaine his gard about him, as Lieuten
a
t gen
r
all
of
Holland,
but hee ys neth
r
acknowledged publikly to bee so, nor any
way employed, or called to counsell eith
r
by
e Governo
r
,
e Count
or by
e Counsell of State, Howbeyt I do
ceave by many spetiall
good tokens,
t
he remayneth as well devoted to hir Ma
ty
as
any of
em all w
th
out exception, w
ch
I thought not im
tinent to
adv
r
tise yo
r
L
& so take my humble leave. N
o
12. 89
